sub_title: Medical Affairs Manager - Benelux at Dexcom
summary:
My extensive supervising and educational experience, along with my excellent communication and networking skills, makes me ideally suited for a MSL/medical advisory position at a pharmaceutical company. I am proactive, enthusiastic and result-driven, engaged with good interpersonal skills. In my spare time I enjoy fine dining and adventurous sports such as scuba and sky diving. 

I studied Biomedical Sciences at Leiden University, The Netherlands, with a minor in Science Based Business. I did my PhD at the department of Endocrinology of the LUMC, The Netherlands. As a scientist, I very much enjoyed communicating scientific information to experts and key opinion leaders, including clinicians and industry professionals from companies such as TNO, Solvay and Abbott. I get a lot of positive energy from transferring knowledge, and therefore I have been involved in the educational program of medical and biomedical students as well as supervised numerous students. With great pleasure I have presented scientific data at many international conferences as well as organized (inter)national conferences myself. I have used various media sources, such as glossy magazines, radio and webinar to communicate my research to lay-audience. I have recently completed the MSL training “from SCIENCE to PHARMA”.

I have extensive experience in interpreting scientific data, as well as writing and reviewing scientific documentation, which has given me a critical and analytical mentality. I am comfortable working either independently or in a team and I have a strong drive to assimilate and master new areas of research. I take pleasure in initiating new contacts as well as maintaining established ones which contributed greatly to the development of my extensive (inter)national network within the fields of endocrinology and neurophysiology.

company.name: The Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson

profile_positions.company: The Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson
profile_positions.description:
As part of the Immunology Medical Affairs team, I participate in objective and balanced medical scientific exchange regarding Guselkumab (Tremfya®) and Ustekinumab (Stelara®). This includes but is not limited to:

• Assure scientific exchange with HCPs and leading specialists
• Organize medical education for HCPs
• Provide scientific education for internal stakeholders 
• Organize and chair scientific exchange meetings (e.g. Medical Education Steering Committees, Ad-Boards)
• Initiate, contribute and guide Educational Grants
• Attend international and national congresses to keep up-to-date on the latest scientific advances and obtain valuable insights from the scientific community
• Contribute to International Business Development and Strategic Decision making.
profile_positions.title: Medical Scientific Liaison Dermatology

profile_positions.description:
The main goal of Catalyze is to support leading researchers and companies secure funding for ambitious R&D projects, from early stage, fundamental research up until late-stage development. 

My role at Catalyze:
* Secured >€12Million in non-dilutive funding for innovative life science companies and contributed to several top-ranked European projects 
* Liaise between academic, biotech and pharmaceutical partners
* Business matchmaking and international consortium building
* Business planning (e.g. market research, sales strategy and value chain analysis)
* Stakeholder and key opinion leader management
* Project management, project planning and budgeting
profile_positions.title: Senior consultant Life Sciences, Biotechnology and Medical Technology

profile_positions.description:
* I showed that disruption of the normal day-night rhythm has severe consequences for the gut microbiota and results in a pro-inflammatory state. 
* Actively participating in departmental meetings, involved in strategic decision making
* Supervising and training of Bachelor-, Master-, PhD-students and technicians  (~7/year)
* Project management, including documentation and financial management
* Writing grant proposals; this project is funded by my personal grants from EFSD/Novo Nordisk, the Dutch Diabetes Research Foundation and the Leids Universiteits Fonds 
* Writing scientific articles and presenting during (inter)national conferences
* Ad hoc reviewer for scientific journals such as Diabetologia, J Neurosc, J Biol Rhythms and funding agency ZonMW as well as the book “ZonWijzer - Meer zicht op zon en licht” by Han van der Rhee
* (Co-)Organizer of the European Biological Rhythms Society Congress (2017), the Dutch Neuroscience Meeting (2017) and departmental integration symposium (2018)
* Teach courses for medical and biomedical students
* https://www.diabetesfonds.nl/wat-we-doen/onderzoek/wat-doet-onze-biologische-klok
profile_positions.title: Principal Investigator at dept. of Cell and Chemical Biology - Neurophysiology

profile_positions.description:
* The results of my work show that disrupting the normal day-night rhythm induces weight gain and can result in the development of diabetes. 
* Key Methods: intravenous, intraperitoneal and subcutaneous injection of mice, stereotactic surgery, in vivo electrophysiology, ELISA, immunohistochemistry
* Other Activities: supervising bachelor, master and PhD students, (poster) presentations at (inter)national conferences, writing articles, writing applications for the animal ethical commitee, writing grant proposals
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral researcher at dept. of Molecular Cell Biology - Neurophysiology

profile_positions.description:
* I discovered that the hormone insulin exerts much of its action on muscle and fat tissue via the brain. 
* This project involved collaborating with various clinical and pre-clinical scientists as well as TNO and the pharmaceutical companies Solvay and Abbott (TI Pharma consortium)
* Thesis defense 14th of June 2012: Insulin sensitivity – modulation by the brain
   See also: https://openaccess.leidenuniv.nl/handle/1887/19084
* Promotors: Prof. J.A. Romijn, Prof. L.M. Havekes and Prof. dr. P.C.N. Rensen
* Collaborations with University of Helsinki (Finland) and the Catholic University of Leuven (Belgium).
* Key Methods: intravenous, intraperitoneal and subcutaneous injection of mice, operation of mice to place catheter in brain ventricle, splenectomy in mice, PCR, ELISA, various enzymatic colorimetric assays, FPLC, TLC, working with radioactive tracers in vivo
* Other activities: supervising bachelor and master students, (poster) presentations at (inter)national conferences, writing articles, writing applications for the animal ethical committee, writing grant proposals
https://www.easd.org/virtualmeeting/home.html#!resources/role-of-brain-insulin-signalling-on-tissue-specific-glucose-disposal
profile_positions.title: PhD student at dept. of Endocrinology

profile_positions.description:
* I investigated the use of magnetic force for ex vivo transfection of hematopoietic stem cells
* Key methods: cell culture, plasmid purification, DNA extraction, bacterial culture, transfection, virus titer-test, intravenous injection of mice
profile_positions.title: Scientific researcher at dept. of Hematology

profile_positions.description:
* I demonstrated the cytotoxicity and therapeutic efficacy of the Bcl-2/Bcl-XL inhibitor ABT-737 alone and in combination with various HDACi's.
* Supervisor: Dr. Ricky Johnstone
* Key methods: cell culture, various apoptosis and cell cycle assays using FACS, intra-peritoneal injection of mice, palpation of mice to follow tumour growth, autopsy of mice
profile_positions.title: Research Internship in Melbourne, Australië

profile_positions.description:
* I demonstrated the binding affinity of apolipoprotein C1-derived peptides to LPS in vitro and in vivo.
* Supervisors: Prof. dr. P. Rensen and Dr. J. Berbée 
* Key methods: cell culture, various elektrophoresis techniques and accompanied stainings, intra-peritoneal injection of mice, operation in mice to simultaneously study serum decay and liver uptake of injected substance in time, autopsy of mice
profile_positions.title: Research internship at Prevention and Health
